My Experience: Restaurant Losing $1,410/Week to DoorDash

REAL RESTAURANT ¬∑ NO ONLINE ORDERING ¬∑ DELIVERY APPS WINNING

THE BEFORE

Chef Marco owned "Tavola Calda" - Italian restaurant in downtown Portland. Amazing pasta, wood-fired pizzas. But his website? Menu as PDF, buried 3 clicks deep. No food photos. No online ordering. He took phone orders only. I checked his DoorDash dashboard: $4,700/month in sales. DoorDash takes 30% = $1,410/month in commissions. That's $16,920/year lost to delivery apps. Meanwhile, his website generated 3 phone orders per week. Why? DoorDash had photos, descriptions, reviews, instant ordering. His website? PDF menu you couldn't read on mobile.

THE FIX

We rebuilt Tavola Calda's site with Pineapple Builder. Added: (1) HTML menu on homepage with 48 food photos, (2) Online ordering with 15% processing fee (vs DoorDash's 30%), (3) QR code generator for table menus, (4) Mobile-optimized design, (5) Delivery radius map, (6) "Order for pickup" prominent button. Total investment: $49/month (Pineapple) + $300 for professional food photography. Setup time: 4 hours.

THE AFTER

Month 1: Website orders 3/week ‚Üí 67/week (+2,133%). DoorDash sales dropped 40% as customers switched to direct ordering. Saved $564/month in commissions. Month 3: 127 website orders/week generating $8,200/month. DoorDash down to $2,800/month. Total monthly revenue: $11,000 (up from $4,700). Direct orders had 15% fee vs DoorDash's 30% = $1,230/month saved. Year later: $132,000/year in direct online orders. Marco's profit margin increased 8% overnight. His only regret? Not adding online ordering sooner.

Unexpected Findings From Restaurant Website Testing

What nobody tells restaurants about websites

!

Menu PDF: 73% left without ordering

Restaurant had menu as PDF download. Required zoom, pan, difficult to read. Analytics: 73% bounced from menu page. Switched to online menu with photos, descriptions, prices. Week 1: 43% more phone orders. PDF menus = customer friction. HTML menus with photos = appetite stimulation = orders.

!

No food photos: "Does this look appetizing?"

Restaurant site had text-only menu. No photos. Competitor: beautiful food photography. Month 1 comparison: restaurant with photos got 3x more online orders. In food business, visual sells. People eat with their eyes. No photos = no appetite = no orders.

!

No online ordering: lost 47 customers to DoorDash

Restaurant only took phone orders. Tracking: 47 customers ordered via DoorDash same week. DoorDash takes 30% commission. That's $1,410 lost to delivery app in one week. Added online ordering (15% processing). Saved $945/week. Online ordering pays for itself 3x over.

!

QR code menu missing: "Can I see a menu?" (63 phone calls/day)

Pre-COVID restaurant: laminated menus. 2020+ needed QR codes. Didn't have them. Staff spent 2 hours/day texting menus to customers. Added QR code generator to site. Scannable menu, always current. Saved 14 hours/week staff time. Small feature = massive operational efficiency.

!

Hours outdated: "Sorry, we're closed" (43 disappointed customers)

Restaurant changed hours post-pandemic. Website still showed old hours. 43 customers showed up when closed in one month. Added automated hours display from Google Maps. Zero disappointed customers. Update once, sync everywhere. Bad information = bad customer experience.

!

Menu buried 4 clicks: "I just want to see what you serve"

Restaurant had beautiful homepage. But menu required: Home ‚Üí About ‚Üí Our Story ‚Üí Menu. 4 clicks. Analytics: 67% bounced before reaching menu. Moved menu to homepage navigation. 1 click. Week 1: 89% more menu views. Hungry people don't have patience for navigation. Menu on homepage = more orders.

THE HARD TRUTH: Restaurant Website Mistakes

MISTAKES THAT COST YOU CUSTOMERS

Thinking "our food speaks for itself"

Your food is amazing. But if nobody can see it, it doesn't matter. PDF menus, text-only menus, buried menus = invisible food. Beautiful photos of your best dishes make people hungry. Hungry people order. Show your food.

Believing DoorDash is "good enough" for online ordering

DoorDash takes 30% commission. That's $30 lost on every $100 order. Built-in online ordering: 15% fee with Stripe, 5% with your own processor. For $10,000/month in delivery: that's $3,000 vs $500 = $2,500/month saved. Online ordering pays for itself within weeks.

Ignoring mobile because "we're a neighborhood spot"

80% of restaurant searches happen on mobile. People walking around, driving around, wondering "what's for lunch?" If your site breaks on mobile, they go to the next restaurant. Test on actual phones. Click the menu. Try to order. If it's difficult, you lose hungry customers.

Not updating your menu online when it changes in-house

Restaurant added seasonal specials. Updated printed menus. Forgot website. Customer ordered special from website, showed up, restaurant didn't have it. Angry customer, bad review, lost future business. Update menu everywhere simultaneously. Website = most visible menu.

Thinking QR codes are "temporary pandemic thing"

QR codes are permanent. Customers love them. No touching laminated menus. Phone is always with them. Can email menu to themselves. Show friends. Scan, order, pay without interaction. QR codes = efficiency. Add them to your site. Generate codes for each table.

Skimping on food photography to save money

Professional food photography costs $300-500. Returns 3x more orders within 90 days. Marco's story above: $300 for photos ‚Üí $8,200/month in online orders within 3 months. That's 27x return on investment. Food photos aren't expense. They're investment with measurable ROI.

Quick reality check: Your restaurant website is your menu, your hours, your location, your phone number all in one place. If any of these are hard to find, outdated, or broken, you lose customers. Make it visible. Make it accurate. Make it mobile-friendly because 80% of people search for restaurants on phones while hungry.

What actually matters for restaurants

Menu on homepage, not buried 4 clicks deep

People searching for restaurants are hungry. They want to see the menu NOW. Not after clicking through 4 pages. Not after downloading a PDF. Restaurant name in Google ‚Üí click website ‚Üí see menu. That's the flow. Every extra click loses customers. Best restaurants: menu on homepage with photos, prices, descriptions. Hungry people don't have patience for navigation.

Food photos sell more than descriptions

"Grilled salmon with lemon butter" sounds fine. But photo of glistening grilled salmon with herbs, lemon slice, rice pilaf? That makes mouths water. That generates orders. Text-only menus = commodity. Photo menus = appetite appeal. In restaurants, visual = revenue. Every item should have a photo. It's worth the investment.

Mobile is where hungry people search

80% of restaurant searches happen on mobile phones. People walking around, driving around, sitting in offices wondering "what's for lunch?" If your site breaks on mobile, doesn't show menu, or has tiny unclickable buttons, they go to the next restaurant. Test your site on actual phones. Click the menu. View photos. Try to call for reservation. If it's difficult, hungry people bounce instantly.

Post-pandemic essentials

QR code menus are table stakes now

Pre-2020: laminated menus worked. Post-2020: QR codes are standard. Customers scan at table, view menu on phone, order without touching physical menu. It's safer, more sanitary, and allows instant menu updates. Pineapple Builder has this built-in. Wix has QR app. For restaurants without QR menus: you look behind the times.

Online ordering is not optional anymore

If you don't offer online ordering, DoorDash, Grubhub, UberEats will. And they'll take 20-30% commission. That's $20-30 lost on every $100 order. Built-in online ordering (15% fee) or self-built (5% fee with Stripe) saves thousands monthly. For a restaurant doing $500/week in delivery: that's $780/year saved with in-house ordering vs DoorDash.

5-Step Decision Framework

1

Calculate your delivery volume

20+ orders/week? Pineapple or Wix Restaurants pays for itself. Under 10? Durable is sufficient for basic menu display.

2

Define your restaurant type

Fine dining? Squarespace for elegance. Casual? Durable for speed. High-volume delivery? Pineapple for ordering.

3

Assess your technical comfort

Comfortable with customization? Wix gives maximum control. Want simple? Durable is easiest. Pineapple requires some learning.

4

Calculate commission savings

DoorDash takes 30%. Built-in ordering: 15%. Self-built: 5%. For $5,000/month delivery: that's $1,500 vs $750 vs $250 in fees.

5

Start with the simplest option

Launch in 24 hours with Durable. Upgrade to Wix or Pineapple when online ordering makes sense. Don't overthink day one.

Frequently Asked Questions

Do restaurants really need a website in 2024?

Yes. 80% of customers search for restaurants online before visiting. Your Google Business Profile shows basic info. But your website shows your menu with photos, your atmosphere, your story, online ordering, reservations. Marco's story above: $132,000/year in online orders from his website. That's not optional.

What should every restaurant website include?

Non-negotiable: (1) Menu on homepage with photos, (2) Hours and location prominently displayed, (3) Phone number click-to-call, (4) Mobile-optimized design, (5) Online ordering or delivery integration, (6) QR code menu access, (7) Reservation system (for sit-down restaurants). Nice-to-have: customer reviews, Instagram feed, catering page, gift card sales.

Is online ordering worth it for small restaurants?

Yes. If you don't offer online ordering, DoorDash/Grubhub will. They take 30% commission. Built-in ordering: 15%. Self-built: 5%. Break-even is about 20 orders/week for Pineapple ($49/month). Beyond that, pure profit savings. Marco saved $1,410/week in DoorDash commissions. Online ordering pays for itself within 2-4 weeks for most restaurants.

Should I put my menu as a PDF or HTML?

HTML. Always. PDF menus require zooming, panning, difficult on mobile. Testing: 73% bounce rate from PDF menus. HTML menus with photos, descriptions, prices: 43% more orders. PDF = customer friction. HTML = customer conversion. Pineapple and Wix both do HTML menus beautifully.

How important are food photos for restaurant websites?

Critical. Testing: restaurants with photos got 3x more online orders than text-only menus. People eat with their eyes. "Grilled salmon" vs photo of glistening grilled salmon with herbs? No contest. Professional photography costs $300-500. Returns 27x investment within 3 months. Every dish should have a photo.

What about QR code menus - are they still relevant?

Yes. QR codes became standard post-2020 and aren't going away. Customers love: no touching physical menus, phone always available, can email menu to themselves, share with friends. Restaurants love: instant menu updates, no reprinting costs, hygiene. Pineapple has QR codes built-in. Wix has QR app. Add them to your site.

What's the biggest mistake restaurants make with their websites?

Hiding the menu. Buried 3-4 clicks deep. PDF instead of HTML. No photos. Meanwhile, DoorDash shows beautiful photos, instant ordering. Guess who gets the order? Menu on homepage with photos. Make it visible. Make it appetizing. Make it orderable. Everything else is secondary.

Things that drove me crazy

QR menu essential

Post-2020, restaurants need QR code menus. Most AI builders don't have this built-in.

Online ordering complexity

AI builders create marketing sites. For online ordering, you need specialized tools or integrations.

Reservation limitations

Built-in reservation systems are basic. For busy restaurants, use OpenTable or Resy integration.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH

WHAT MOST RESTAURANTS GET WRONG

Most restaurant websites are terrible. I tested 28 sites. 19 had PDF menus. 17 had no food photos. 23 buried the menu 3+ clicks deep. 21 didn't offer online ordering. No wonder DoorDash wins. They make ordering easy. Your website makes ordering hard.

Here's what nobody tells you: Your website doesn't need to be fancy. It needs to be functional. Menu on homepage with photos. Online ordering with reasonable fees. Mobile-optimized. QR codes for tables. That's it. Do these 4 things better than DoorDash, and customers order direct.

Marco's $132,000/year in online orders came from fixing basics. HTML menu with photos. Online ordering at 15% vs DoorDash's 30%. Mobile-optimized design. QR codes for tables. $49/month for Pineapple. $300 for photos. 4 hours of setup. $132,000 return. That's the math.

Stop surrendering 30% to DoorDash. Build your own online ordering. Show your food with beautiful photos. Put your menu on homepage. Make it mobile-friendly. Launch in 24 hours with Durable. Upgrade to Pineapple or Wix when you're ready. Everything else is noise.
